testimony.name: Mark Levine
key_points: The city is experiencing a severe housing shortage and high rents
Current zoning code from 1961 is an obstacle to building needed housing
City of Yes for Housing Opportunity would help alleviate the housing shortage
Universal Affordable Preference (UAP) would increase affordable housing stock
The proposal would reduce roadblocks for converting vacant offices to residential units
Changes would allow for development on large residential campuses, including those owned by faith-based organizations
Manhattan Borough Board approved 15 key recommendations in the proposal
The proposal could potentially catalyze the production of 100,000 new units

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: The proposal for universal affordable pre affordability preference promises to significantly increase our affordable housing stock throughout Manhattan with a relatively low income target of 60% AMI.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote directly mentions the Universal Affordability Preference (UAP) element of the proposal, discussing its potential to increase affordable housing in Manhattan with a specific income target.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: In order to ensure that UAP is maximized, I recommend that CPC be required to certify that the UAP option has been effectively used by condo and co op developments prior to eliminating the off-site option.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote further discusses the UAP element, providing recommendations for its implementation and maximization.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: City of Yes for housing opportunity would also reduce roadblocks for the conversion of vacant and underutilized offices into residential and unlock unlock a projected 6000 units over the next 16 years.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote directly addresses the Residential Conversions element of the proposal, mentioning the conversion of vacant offices into residential units and providing a specific projection of units that could be created.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Our current zoning code makes it hard to convert vacant office buildings to residences.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote identifies the current problem that the Residential Conversions element of the proposal aims to address.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: It leaves little housing next to some transit hubs, and prevents apartments from being built on top of stores in some commercial districts.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote indirectly addresses the Town Center Zoning element by mentioning the current limitations on building apartments above stores in commercial districts, which is a key aspect of the Town Center Zoning proposal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: It prioritizes construction of parking over apartments.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote indirectly addresses the issue of parking mandates by highlighting the current problem of prioritizing parking construction over housing, which the Removing Parking Mandates element aims to address.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: It leaves little housing next to some transit hubs
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote indirectly addresses the Transit-Oriented Development element by mentioning the current lack of housing near transit hubs, which is a key issue that the Transit-Oriented Development proposal aims to address.
